repnme.cdata!:
Tunisia - Employment Development Policy
            Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Employment Development
            Policy Loan Project for Tunisia were as follows: outcomes
            were moderately unsatisfactory, the risk to development
            outcome was moderate, the Bank performance was satisfactory,
            and the Borrower performance was also satisfactory. Some
            lessons learned included: the Bank should not expect too
            much from consultations with stakeholders in a country
            tightly controlled by the security apparatus. In the
            interviews carried out for the preparation of the completion
            report, most interlocutors complained that there had been
            too little consultation in the development of the reform
            program. In a society undermined by deep corruption and
            cronyism, statements from the ruling elite should not be
            taken at face value. In his electoral program for 2009-2014,
            President Ben Ali made employment a national priority. He
            promised reforms to address the unemployment and social
            protection challenges. While he made his speeches, he was
            strengthening the rent seeking system which was stifling
            entrepreneurship and job creation. The previous regime,
            which seemed to be well entrenched, was swept away in a
            short period of time. Solid political economy analyses are
            essential to better understand the constraints and
            frustrations in a country where opportunities are scant
            because of deeply embedded corruption.

docna.cdata!: Tunisia - Employment Development Policy Loan Project

Tunisia - Employment Development
            Policy Loan Project  : Tunisia - Employment Development

abstracts.cdata!:
This Results Profile talks about
            boosting the employment in Tunisia. In spite of solid
            growth, unemployment remained persistent in Tunisia. To help
            Tunisia address persistently high unemployment, particularly
            among youth, the World Bank had provided both technical and
            financial support to underpin critical labor market reforms.
            The Development Policy Loan, prepared by the Bank, reformed
            operations and processes of the public employment services
            to enhance efficiency and effectiveness for long term employment.

repnme.cdata!:
Tunisia - Employment Development Policy
            Loan Program

abstracts.cdata!:
The Employment Development Policy Loan
            Program as part of the overall program's objective of
            improving the effectiveness and efficiency of job entry in
            Tunisia, this first Development Policy Loan (DPL) will
            improve active labor market programs, labor intermediation
            and the information base for guiding employment policies.
            The Government of Tunisia declared employment the number one
            priority in its Eleventh National Development Plan (NDP-XI)
            2007-2011. Achieving a lower unemployment rate will require
            demand side interventions, including private sector
            development, increased competitiveness, and innovation;
            supply side interventions, including education and
            vocational training systems; and effective labor market
            intermediation to match demand and supply. This program
            document (PD) summarizes the program agreed during the last
            12 months during various missions, by the Bank, the European
            Commission (EC), and representatives of the Government. The
            identified policy matrix covers: (i) short-term measures
            supported by this first DPL (DPL I), to be realized by May
            2010, (ii) potential medium-term measures, to be realized in
            a second DPL (DPL II) by mid 2011, and (iii) a shared vision
            of achievements, to be realized by the end of this 5-year
            program. It also contains performance indicators to be
            achieved by May 2012 (one year after the end of DPL II).

docna.cdata!: Tunisia - Employment Development Policy Loan Program

display_title.display_title:
Tunisia - Employment Development
            Policy Loan Program

            Loan Program
